text:
A great many of the classes implement "Constants" interfaces (at least in the 
svggen package).  While convenient, users may (I know I did) mistake these 
constants for values that should be passed to the public API's instead of the 
implementation detail that they really represent.  Sun's Joshua Bloch's Item 17 
of his excellent book "Effective Java" is titled "Use interfaces only to define 
types."  This is good advice for anyone providing code for public use.

My proposal is to change the constants interface into an uninstantiable class 
with public constants, and all the references to the constants will have to be 
changed to reference it's constants.  The way I make a class uninstantiable, is 
by providing a private constructor.
